definitions: required to justify actions or decisions to someone in authority
able to be explained or understood in a logical way
examples: The CEO is accountable to the board of directors
Public officials must remain accountable for their actions
These discrepancies are accountable by simple human error
The sudden temperature change is accountable through meteorological patterns

definitions: officially recognized as meeting required standards by an authorized body
having received official certification or credentials for a specific role
examples: She graduated from an accredited medical school
The laboratory must be accredited before conducting tests
Only accredited journalists can attend the press conference
He's an accredited representative of the embassy

definitions: accumulated or received over a period of time through natural growth
legally earned or owed but not yet received or paid
examples: The accrued interest on the savings account was substantial
They donated their accrued vacation days to charity
Accrued benefits become payable upon retirement
The company must pay all accrued wages to employees

definitions: gathered or collected over a period of time in increasing quantity
gradually built up or amassed through continuous addition or growth
examples: The accumulated dust on the shelves was inches thick
Years of accumulated knowledge made her an expert
The accumulated stress finally took its toll on his health
Their accumulated wealth came from decades of saving

definitions: correct in all details and free from errors or mistakes
conforming exactly to truth or to a standard with careful precision
examples: The weather forecast proved remarkably accurate this week
Her accurate assessment helped solve the problem quickly
The surgeon needs accurate measurements before the operation
This scale provides accurate readings to three decimal places

definitions: believed to be under a curse or spell bringing misfortune
causing or deserving strong dislike and annoyance in informal use
examples: The accursed tomb brought disaster to all who entered
They fled from the accursed place before nightfall
This accursed printer jams every time I use it
I can't find my accursed keys anywhere today

definitions: showing or expressing blame or the belief that someone has done wrong
having a quality that suggests someone is guilty or at fault
examples: She gave him an accusing look when he arrived late
His accusing tone made everyone uncomfortable in the meeting
The accusing evidence was presented to the jury
There were accusing fingerprints all over the crime scene

definitions: familiar with something through repeated experience or long use
being in the habit of doing something as normal behavior
examples: She grew accustomed to the noise of city traffic
His eyes became accustomed to the darkness slowly
They were accustomed to dining at eight every evening
I'm not accustomed to such formal treatment here

definitions: of the highest quality or extremely good at something
showing exceptional skill or expertise in a particular area
examples: She's an ace detective with twenty years experience
The restaurant serves ace food at reasonable prices
He's ace at fixing computers and electronic devices
Their ace pitcher won fifteen games this season

definitions: sharp and harsh in manner or tone especially in speech or writing
having a sour or bitter taste that is sharp and unpleasant
examples: His acerbic wit often offended sensitive colleagues
The critic's acerbic review destroyed the play's reputation
The acerbic flavor of unripe fruit made her wince
This wine has an acerbic aftertaste that lingers

definitions: relating to or containing acetic acid found in vinegar
containing or derived from the acetate radical in chemistry
examples: The acetic smell of vinegar filled the kitchen
Acetic acid is the main component of vinegar
The acetic compound was used in the chemical reaction
They studied various acetic derivatives in the laboratory

definitions: able to be accomplished or brought to successful completion
realistic and possible to attain within practical constraints or limitations
examples: Setting achievable goals helps maintain motivation throughout projects
This target is achievable with our current resources
The deadline seems achievable if everyone works efficiently together
They focused on achievable solutions rather than ideal ones

definitions: suffering from or characterized by a continuous dull pain
filled with or expressing deep longing or emotional pain
examples: Her aching muscles needed rest after the marathon
The aching tooth kept him awake all night long
She felt an aching loneliness after he left town
His aching heart yearned for his distant homeland

definitions: sharp, biting, or sarcastic in speech, manner, or temper
having the properties of an acid with pH less than seven
examples: Her acid remarks about his appearance hurt deeply
The comedian's acid humor wasn't appreciated by everyone
The acid solution must be handled with extreme care
Acid rain damages buildings and natural ecosystems significantly

definitions: containing acid or having the properties of an acid chemically
having a sharp, sour taste characteristic of acids
examples: The soil is too acidic for these plants to thrive
Acidic foods can damage tooth enamel over time
The wine had an unpleasant acidic taste this year
Lemons are naturally acidic fruits rich in citric acid

definitions: accepted or recognized as true, valid, or legitimate by others
publicly recognized for achievement or expertise in a particular field
examples: It's an acknowledged fact that exercise improves health
The acknowledged risks were outlined in the contract
She's the acknowledged expert on medieval French literature
He became the acknowledged leader of the movement

definitions: relating to sound, the sense of hearing, or the science of sound
using natural sound without electronic amplification especially of musical instruments
examples: The acoustic properties of the concert hall are excellent
They installed acoustic panels to reduce echo
She prefers acoustic guitar to electric for folk songs
The band played an intimate acoustic set last night

definitions: relating to the science or physical properties of sound
specifically designed or used for controlling or improving sound quality
examples: The acoustical engineer designed the recording studio perfectly
They conducted acoustical measurements in the auditorium
Acoustical tiles help reduce noise in office spaces
The acoustical treatment improved the room's sound dramatically

definitions: having met and knowing someone personally though not intimately
having knowledge or experience of something through contact or observation
examples: I'm acquainted with your sister from college days
They became acquainted at the conference last year
She's well acquainted with the local customs here
You should get acquainted with the safety procedures

definitions: obtained or gained after birth rather than naturally present
developed or learned through experience rather than being innate
examples: His acquired wealth came from smart investments over time
The company's acquired assets doubled its market value
She has an acquired taste for classical music
These are acquired skills that take years to develop

definitions: formally declared not guilty of a criminal charge by a verdict
conducted oneself or performed in a specified way in a situation
examples: The acquitted defendant left the courthouse immediately
All acquitted suspects were released from custody
She acquitted herself admirably during the crisis
The team acquitted themselves well in the tournament

definitions: characterized by harsh or bitter sharpness in speech, manner, or temper
examples: The acrimonious divorce proceedings lasted for two years
Their acrimonious debate ended with both parties storming out
The meeting turned acrimonious when budgets were discussed
Years of acrimonious disputes had destroyed their friendship

definitions: involving or performing spectacular gymnastic feats requiring agility and balance
requiring or displaying physical skill, agility, and coordination
examples: The acrobatic performance amazed the circus audience completely
Her acrobatic dive earned perfect scores from judges
The goalkeeper made an acrobatic save in overtime
The dancer's acrobatic moves required years of training

definitions: temporarily doing the duties of another person's job or position
relating to the art or profession of performing in plays or films
examples: The acting director will serve until April next year
She was appointed acting CEO during the transition
His acting career began in community theater productions
The acting coach helped improve her stage presence

definitions: providing sufficient grounds for a lawsuit or other legal action
able to be acted upon or implemented practically and effectively
examples: The lawyer determined the complaint was legally actionable
They gathered actionable evidence of corporate fraud
The report contained actionable recommendations for improvement
We need actionable insights from this data analysis

definitions: made active or operational especially by an external stimulus or trigger
treated chemically or physically to increase reactivity or absorption capacity
examples: The activated alarm system detected the intruder immediately
Once activated, the device cannot be turned off
Activated charcoal helps remove toxins from the body
The activated carbon filter purifies the water effectively

definitions: causing something to become active or operational when triggered
stimulating or initiating a process, reaction, or response
examples: The activating signal triggered the emergency response system
Pressing this activating button starts the entire sequence
The activating enzyme begins the digestive process immediately
Light serves as an activating factor for photosynthesis

definitions: characterized by physical movement, energy, and regular exercise
currently functioning, working, or in operation rather than inactive
engaged in or ready for practical action rather than passive
examples: She maintains an active lifestyle with daily exercise
Active children need plenty of outdoor play time
The volcano has been active for three months now
Keep your subscription active by paying the annual fee
He's an active member of the community board
Students learn better through active participation in class

definitions: characterized by vigorous action or involvement in a cause
engaged in or promoting political or social change through direct action
examples: The activist approach to investing focuses on corporate change
She takes an activist stance on environmental issues
Activist groups organized protests throughout the city
The activist judge was known for progressive rulings

definitions: existing in fact or reality rather than imagined or supposed
existing now or at the time being considered rather than potential
examples: The actual cost exceeded the original estimate significantly
Her actual words were much harsher than reported
The actual temperature is higher than the forecast predicted
What's the actual time of arrival for the flight?

definitions: relating to the statistical calculation of insurance risks and premiums
examples: The actuarial analysis determined the insurance premium rates
She works in the actuarial department of the company
Actuarial tables help predict life expectancy for populations
The pension fund requires regular actuarial valuations

definitions: operated or controlled by a mechanical or automatic device
motivated or moved to action by a particular feeling or belief
examples: The actuated valve opens when pressure exceeds limits
These actuated systems require regular maintenance checks
She was actuated by a desire to help others
His decision was actuated by purely selfish motives

definitions: severe or intense especially when describing pain, illness, or problems
having or showing keen mental perception and intellectual insight
forming an angle of less than ninety degrees in geometry
examples: She was admitted with acute abdominal pain last night
The hospital treats acute medical emergencies twenty-four seven
His acute observations helped solve the complex mystery
She has an acute sense of social dynamics
Draw an acute angle measuring forty-five degrees precisely
The triangle has three acute angles

definitions: played slowly and gracefully in musical performance or composition
examples: The adagio movement brought tears to the audience
She performed the adagio passage with emotional depth
The ballet dancers moved in adagio tempo across stage
This adagio section requires careful breath control

definitions: refusing to be persuaded or to change one's mind about something
extremely hard and impossible to break or penetrate like diamond
examples: She remained adamant about her decision to resign
He was adamant that the rules must be followed
The adamant fortress walls withstood every attack attempt
They encountered adamant rock during the excavation

definitions: able to adjust to different conditions or circumstances flexibly
capable of being modified or changed to suit different purposes
examples: Successful managers must be adaptable to changing markets
She's remarkably adaptable to new cultural environments
This adaptable design works for multiple room configurations
The software is adaptable to various operating systems

definitions: modified or changed to become suitable for a new purpose or situation
having evolved characteristics suited to a particular environment or way of life
examples: The adapted screenplay won an Academy Award this year
These adapted textbooks meet special education needs perfectly
Desert plants are adapted to conserve water efficiently
Polar bears are perfectly adapted to Arctic conditions

definitions: showing or having the ability to adapt to different conditions
relating to or characterized by adaptation in biological or technological contexts
examples: Adaptive behavior helps organisms survive environmental changes
The adaptive response was faster than scientists expected
This adaptive technology adjusts to user preferences automatically
Adaptive learning systems personalize education for each student

definitions: physically dependent on a substance with harmful effects when deprived
devoted to a particular interest or activity to an excessive degree
examples: He became addicted to painkillers after his surgery
Many people are addicted to nicotine without realizing it
She's completely addicted to social media these days
I'm addicted to this new television series

definitions: causing or likely to cause someone to become physically dependent
so enjoyable or compelling that one wants to repeat it frequently
examples: These painkillers are highly addictive and require monitoring
Nicotine is one of the most addictive substances known
This game is so addictive I played all night
Her writing style is addictive and keeps readers engaged

definitions: added, extra, or supplementary to what is already present or available
examples: Additional fees may apply for express shipping service
We need additional funding to complete the project
Please provide additional information about your experience
The committee requested additional time to review proposals

definitions: characterized by or relating to addition rather than replacement
relating to substances added to improve or preserve something
examples: The additive effect of these drugs requires careful monitoring
Colors combine in additive mixing to create white light
Food contains additive chemicals to extend shelf life
This gasoline includes an additive for better performance

definitions: capable of receiving data or communications at a specific address
capable of being dealt with, solved, or remedied effectively
examples: Each addressable device has a unique network identifier
The addressable memory space determines system capacity
These concerns are addressable through policy changes
Most customer complaints are easily addressable issues

definitions: directed to a particular person or group as the recipient
dealt with or given attention to resolve or discuss
examples: The addressed envelope was ready for mailing immediately
This letter is addressed to the board president
The addressed concerns led to immediate policy changes
All addressed issues were resolved within the week

definitions: very skilled or proficient at something through practice and experience
examples: She's adept at handling difficult customer complaints professionally
The surgeon was adept with the latest surgical techniques
He became adept at reading body language over time
They're particularly adept in crisis management situations

definitions: sufficient in quantity or amount to meet a particular need or requirement
acceptable in quality though not exceptional or outstanding
examples: The funding is adequate to complete the first phase
Do we have adequate supplies for the entire trip?
Her performance was adequate but not exceptional this quarter
The hotel provided adequate accommodation for our needs

definitions: sticking firmly to a surface or object through physical attachment
following or supporting a particular belief, cause, or leader closely
examples: The adherent coating protects metal from rust effectively
Remove any adherent tissue before applying the bandage
He remained adherent to his principles despite pressure
The adherent followers never questioned their leader's decisions

definitions: able to stick fast to a surface or object through molecular forces
examples: The adhesive tape held the package securely closed
This adhesive bandage stays on even when wet
The adhesive properties of the glue are incredibly strong
They developed a new adhesive material for spacecraft

definitions: next to or adjoining something else with a common boundary or point
examples: The hotel is adjacent to the convention center downtown
Their offices are in adjacent buildings on Main Street
Park in the adjacent lot if this one is full
The adjacent rooms share a connecting door

definitions: relating to or functioning as an adjective in grammatical terms
examples: The adjectival phrase modifies the noun in this sentence
She studied adjectival agreement in French grammar class
This word has both adjectival and adverbial uses
The adjectival clause provides essential information here
